Authors: Weinstock I.A., Atalla R.H., Reiner R.S., Moen M.A., Hammel K.E., Houtman C.J., Hill C.L., Harrup M.K.
Title: A new environmentally benign technology for transforming wood pulp into paper, engineering polyoxometalates as catalysts for multiple processes
Source title: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
Affiliations: USDA Forest Service, Forest Products Laboratory, One Gifford Pinchot Drive, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Department of Chemistry, Emory University, Atlanta, GA 30322, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weinstock, I.A., USDA Forest Service, Forest Products Laboratory, One Gifford Pinchot Drive, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Atalla, R.H., USDA Forest Service, Forest Products Laboratory, One Gifford Pinchot Drive, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Reiner, R.S., USDA Forest Service, Forest Products Laboratory, One Gifford Pinchot Drive, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Moen, M.A., USDA Forest Service, Forest Products Laboratory, One Gifford Pinchot Drive, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Hammel, K.E., USDA Forest Service, Forest Products Laboratory, One Gifford Pinchot Drive, Madison, WI 53705, United States; Houtman, C.J., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Hill, C.L., Department of Chemistry, Emory University, Atlanta, GA 30322, United States; Harrup, M.K., Department of Chemistry, Emory University, Atlanta, GA 30322, United States
Abstract: A new environmentally benign technology, based on the use of polyoxometalate (POM) salts and oxygen, is being developed to bleach wood pulps for use in the manufacture of paper. Details of POM chemistry relating to the unit operations of all effluent-free bleaching process are reported. These include anaerobic delignification of wood pulp, aerobic reoxidation of reduced POMs for their cyclic reuse and POM catalyzed and initiated aerobic mineralization (wet oxidation) of lignin fragments removed from pulp during bleaching. The results of bleaching trials using a series of isostructural POM complexes of the Keggin family are reported. Key structural components of the POMs are varied to determine the effects of these changes on POM performance. Homogeneous reactions of lignin-model compounds with select POMs are used to help interpret kinetic data obtained in the heterogeneous reaction of POM solutions with pulp fibers. Finally, new directions in catalyst design that promise to expand the potential of the technology are discussed.
Author Keywords: Oxidative bleaching; Oxidative delignification; Oxygen; Paper; Polyoxometalates; Wood pulp

Authors: Staicovici Stefan, Wu Chung-Yuan, Benatar Avraham
Title: Welding and disassembly of microwave welded HDPE bars
Source title: Annual Technical Conference - ANTEC, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Staicovici, Stefan, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, United States; Wu, Chung-Yuan, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, United States; Benatar, Avraham, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, United States
Abstract: Microwave welding of polymers is performed by placing an electromagnetic absorbent material (polyaniline) at the interface. The absorbent polyaniline converts electromagnetic energy into heat which is conducted into the bulk materials forming molten layers. Pressure, which applied after the heating stage squeezes the molten layers to form the welded joint. However, if sufficient conductive polymer is retained at the interface, then the welded samples can be placed in the microwave, reheated, and disassembly for recycling and reuse purposes can be performed. Controlling the amount of remaining conductive polymer at the joint interface is the key for achieving disassembly of a microwave welded joint. For this purpose the total displacement was used to characterize both the welding and the disassembly processes. The effect of displacement on joint strength was analyzed. It was found that if the total displacement exceeded 2.7 mm, regardless of the polyaniline concentration (30, 40, 50, 60%) and welding parameters employed, a joint strength of at least 90% the bulk strength is obtained. Disassembly of butt welded joints was then performed. It was found that a joint with a tensile strength of approximately 60% of the bulk strength can be disassembled with a relatively low force of 27 N. However, a long reheating time of 120 seconds and a high power level of 2000 W is required for disassembly to occur. In order to increase the disassembly capability a tuned single-mode microwave system was used. Thus, while the reheating time and power level decreased to 30 seconds, respectively 1000 W, the maximum joint strength which can be disassembled increased to 80% of the bulk strength. The maximum displacement which can be disassembled was found to be 1 mm regardless of the concentration of PANI used. After disassembly the 60% PANI samples were welded once more with the same parameters as the original welds. Tho rewelded samples exhibited a maximum loss of 15% in tensile strength.
Index Keywords: Butt welding; Conductive plastics; Electric welding; Interfaces (materials); Joints (structural components); Microwave heating; Tensile strength; Microwave welding; Polyanilines; High density polyethylenes

Authors: Gokhale Maya, Kaba James, Marks Aaron, Kim Jang
Title: Malleable architecture generator for FPGA computing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: David Sarnoff Research Cent.,, Princeton, NJ, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gokhale, Maya, David Sarnoff Research Cent.,, Princeton, NJ, USA, United States; Kaba, James, David Sarnoff Research Cent.,, Princeton, NJ, USA, United States; Marks, Aaron, David Sarnoff Research Cent.,, Princeton, NJ, USA, United States; Kim, Jang, David Sarnoff Research Cent.,, Princeton, NJ, USA, United States
Abstract: The malleable architecture generator (MARGE) is a tool set that translates high-level parallel C to configuration bit streams for field-programmable logic based computing systems. MARGE creates an application-specific instruction set and generates the custom hardware components required to perform exactly those computations specified by the C program. In contrast to traditional fixed-instruction processors, MARGE's dynamic instruction set creation provides for efficient use of hardware resources. MARGE processes intermediate code in which each operation is annotated by the bit lengths of the operands. Each basic block (sequence of straight line code) is mapped into a single custom instruction which contains all the operations and logic inherent in the block. A synthesis phase maps the operations comprising the instructions into register transfer level structural components and control logic which have been optimized to exploit functional parallelism and function unit reuse. As a final stage, commercial technology-specific tools are used to generate configuration bit streams for the desired target hardware. Technology- specific pre-placed, pre-routed macro blocks are utilized to implement as much of the hardware as possible. MARGE currently supports the Xilinx-based Splash-2 reconfigurable accelerator and National Semiconductor's CLAy-based parallel accelerator, MAPA. The MARGE approach has been demonstrated on systolic applications such as DNA sequence comparison.
Index Keywords: Field programmable logic; Malleable architecture generators; C (programming language); Computer architecture; Computer hardware; DNA sequences; High level languages; Logic devices; Computer programming

Authors: Hartland R.P., Fontaine T., Debeaupuis J.-P., Simenel C., Delepierre M., Latgé J.-P.
Title: A novel β-(1-3)-glucanosyltransferase from the cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus
Affiliations: Aspergillus Laboratory, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France; Lab. of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France; School of Biomedical Sciences, Curtin University of Technology, G. P. O. Box U1987, Perth, WA 6001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Hartland, R.P., Aspergillus Laboratory, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France, School of Biomedical Sciences, Curtin University of Technology, G. P. O. Box U1987, Perth, WA 6001, Australia; Fontaine, T., Aspergillus Laboratory, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France; Debeaupuis, J.-P., Aspergillus Laboratory, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France; Simenel, C., Lab. of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France; Delepierre, M., Lab. of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France; Latgé, J.-P., Aspergillus Laboratory, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Docteur Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France
Abstract: Cell wall transferases utilizing β-(1-3)-glucan chains as substrates may play important roles in cell wall assembly and rearrangement, as β-(1- 3)-glucan is a major structural component of the cell wall of many fungi. A novel β-(1-3)-glucanosyltransferase was purified to apparent homogeneity from an autolysate of the cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus. The enzyme had a molecular mass of 49 kDa and contained approximately 5 kDa of N-linked carbohydrate. The enzyme catalyzed an initial endo-type splitting of a β- (1-3)-glucan molecule, followed by linkage of the newly generated reducing end to the nonreducing end of another β-(1-3)-glucan molecule. Laminarioligosaccharides of size G10 and greater were donor substrates for the transferase. Laminarioligosaccharides of size G5 and greater formed acceptors. The enzyme was able to reuse initial transferase products as donors and acceptors in extended incubations, resulting in the formation of increasingly larger transferase products until they became insoluble. The major initial products from an incubation of the transferase with borohydride-reduced G11 (rG11) were rG6 and rG16. 1H NMR analysis of the rG16 transferase product showed it was a laminarioligosaccharide, indicating that the enzyme forms a β-(1-3)-linkage during transfer. The enzyme may have a key function in vivo by allowing the integration of newly synthesized glucan into the wall and promoting cell wall expansion during cell growth.

Authors: Cook S.A.
Title: X-33 reusable launch vehicle structural technologies
Source title: Space Plane and Hypersonic Systems and Technology Conference
Affiliations: Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cook, S.A., Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States
Abstract: The goal of the Reusable Launch Vehicle (RLV) technology program is to mature the technologies essential for a next-generation reusable launch system capable of reliably serving National space transportation needs at substantially reduced costs. A key part of this program is the X-33 advanced technology demonstrator. The X-33 is an experimental Single Stage to Orbit (SSTO) rocket proof-of-concept demonstrator. The X-33 system must prove the concept of a next-generation system by demonstrating key technology, operations, and reliability requirements in an integrated flight vehicle. The X-33 will fly in 1999.Critical characteristics of SSTO systems, such as the structural/thermal concept, aircraft-like operations and maintenance concepts, flight dynamics, flight loads, ascent and entry environments, mass fraction, fabrication methods, etc., will be incorporated into the X-33 system. The X- 33 will be an automated, suborbital, experimental, single-stage rocket flight vehicle capable of Mach 15 flight. Three basic classes of X-33 / RLV have been investigated: vertical takeoff, horizontal landing (VTHL) wing-body, vertical takeoff, horizontal landing (VTHL) lifting-body, and vertical takeoff, vertical landing (VTVL) concepts. The Lockheed Martin Skunkworks was chosen in July of 1996 to build and fly the X-33. Full reusability presents several unique structural challenges. While the RLV system must be lightweight enough to achieve orbit with payload, it must also be robust enough to be operated in a costeffective manner. The system is further complicated by the fact that conventional ascent-only systems (i.e., cryogenic propellant tanks) must now withstand reentry environments. Thus, an integrated structural / system must be developed and demonstrated. Use of graphite-composites for major structural components appears to be the most feasible near-term solution. The X-33 will draw upon extensive advanced military and commercial aircraft experience to demonstrate composite material systems in RLV environments. A combination of both ground and flight testing will subject these systems to the natural and induced (acoustics, ascent and reentry aerodynamic loads, etc.) environments of multiple launch and reentry. © 1996 by American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics,Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sawyer J.W.
Title: Graphite-composite primary structure for reusable launch vehicles
Affiliations: NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sawyer, J.W., NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA, United States
Abstract: The use of graphite-composites as primary structure is essential for the development of a cost-effective reusable launch vehicle (RLV) to replace the Space Shuttle. Considerable effort has been expended in the past two years by NASA and RLV aerospace industry teams to develop the technology required for the application of graphite-composite material to the primary structures on an RLV. The technology development has focused on three major structural components―intertank, wing, and thrust structure. Major-large scale structural test articles representative of each component have been designed and fabricated and have been or are being tested to verify the design, analysis, and fabrication technology. The results to date show that graphite-composite materials can be used as primary structures on an RLV and their application will result in considerable weight savings over that for conventional aluminum structure. Using higher-temperature composite materials such as the graphite/bismaelimide material results in additional savings in thermal protection system weights for the wing and intertank and in an over-temperature capability for the thrust structure. © 1996 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.

Authors: James G., Roach D., Hansche B., Meza R., Robinson N.
Title: Health monitoring studies on composite structures for aerospace applications
Source title: Engineering, Construction, and Operations in Space V
Affiliations: Design Evaluation and Test Technology Center, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87185-0557, United States; Civil Engineering Department, University of Texas, El Paso, TX 79968-0516, United States; Aerospace Engineering Sciences Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 80309-0429, United States

Abstract: This paper discusses ongoing work to develop structural health monitoring techniques for composite aerospace structures such as aircraft control surfaces, fuselage sections or repairs, and reusable launch vehicle fuel tanks. The overall project is divided into four tasks: operational evaluation, diagnostic measurements, information condensation, and damage detection. Five composite plates were constructed to study delaminations, disbonds, and fluid retention issues as the initial step in creating an operational system. These two foot by two foot plates were graphite-epoxy with nomex honeycomb cores. The diagnostic measurements are composed of modal tests with a scanning laser vibrometer at over 500 scan points per plate covering the frequency range up to 2000 Hz. This data has been reduced into experimental dynamic-response matrices using a generic software package developed at the University of Colorado at Boulder. The continuing effort will entail performing a series of damage identification studies to detect, localize, and determine the extent of the damage. This work is providing understanding and algorithm development for a global NDE technique for composite aerospace structures. © 1996 American Society of Civil Engineers.

Authors: Brungraber Robert L.
Title: Recent heavy timber construction in New England
Affiliations: Benson Woodworking Co, Inc, New Hampshire, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brungraber, Robert L., Benson Woodworking Co, Inc, New Hampshire, United States
Abstract: New England has a rich tradition in heavy timber framing. For two hundred and fifty years, most permanent housing, industrial buildings, public meeting buildings, and bridges were built with large and long native solid-sawn timbers. The past twenty years has seen a remarkable rebirth of these traditional, 'all-wood' methods of connecting heavy timbers to one another with pegged mortises and tenons. This talk touches on assessing the capacities of those joints. The reborn timber framing industry started by building homes and remains firmly based in residential construction. Over the last few years, however, the timber framers have gotten more involved in commercial construction projects. One way timber framers get dry, but large, solid-sawn timbers is to reuse timbers salvaged and resawn from dismantled industrial facilities. This talk will cover a few of the more pressing items confronting the reusers of these magnificent remnants of our primeval forests. Finally, this talk will highlight some of the activities of the ten year old, 400 member, Timber Framers' Guild of North America.

Authors: VerGow Zachary, Bras Bert
Title: Recycling oriented fasteners: a critical evaluation of VDI 2243's selection table
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Design Engineering Division (Publication) DE
Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Authors with affiliations: VerGow, Zachary, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States; Bras, Bert, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Abstract: A growing concern about the environment, and especially about waste and landfill, has spurred research into the design of more environmentally benign products. A dramatic reduction in environmental impact can be made by recycling. A critical issue in recycling is the separation of joints in the disassembly process. In product recycling (also referred to as reuse) non-destructive disassembly is desired, whereas in material recycling destructive disassembly is allowed (e.g., shredding). This has an impact on the selection of fasteners. In this paper, we provide an overview of the issues involved and specifically we evaluate the selection of fasteners in the context of product recycling, material recycling, and technical aspects as documented in the new German standard VDI 2243, 'Designing Technical Products for Ease of Recycling - Fundamentals and Rules for Design'. The results of this evaluation provide insight in future areas of research and fastener selection models for life cycle design.

Authors: Stubbs D.M., Housman R.J.
Title: Design fundamentals of electroformed components
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Lockheed Palo Alto Research Laboratories, 3251 Hanover Street, Palo Alto, CA  94304, United States; Optical Radiation Corporation, 1300 Optical Drive, Azusa, CA  91702, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stubbs, D.M., Lockheed Palo Alto Research Laboratories, 3251 Hanover Street, Palo Alto, CA  94304, United States; Housman, R.J., Optical Radiation Corporation, 1300 Optical Drive, Azusa, CA  91702, United States
Abstract: This paper is a compilation of process and design information to aid engineers in the creation of components suited for the electroforming manufacturing process. It should be used as a "rule of thumb" to aid in the initial layout phase for designing electroformed parts. Production cost saving design features for various optical and structural components will be discussed; e.g., mirrors and coldshields. Electroforming is the process of depositing metal ions of a given metal or metal alloy onto an electrically conductive mandrel; typically 6061-T6 aluminum alloy for disposable mandrels and stainless steel for reusable mandrels. In the plating process, metal ions are deposited at the cathode (i.e., on the mandrel); the thickness of the deposit is determined by the length of time and current. Once the deposit is at the desired thickness, the mandrel is removed from the plating bath. The electroform is then separated from the mandrel (for a reusable mandrel) or the mandrel is dissolved in a sodium hydroxide solution (for an aluminum mandrel). In either case, the result is a free-standing electroform that is an exact replica of the mandrel. Many components may be manufactured by electroforming, including metal optics such as searchlight mirrors, and precision structural components like coldshields. All are manufactured by a similar process but key differences require tailored manufacturing planning. This paper will discuss these design and manufacturing differences. For example, high quantity, low cost, production parts can utilize reusable steel mandrels if the component design meets certain shape requirements. The application and optical performance of interior and exterior coatings for electroformed components will be discussed. Photographs, graphs, and charts will be utilized throughout the paper to illustrate component design features, material properties, and optical performance. © 1993 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Cyclones create unpredictable wind effects due to their whirling action. Industrial structures in process of erection are particularly susceptible to failure during such unpredictable natural events. A case study of such a failure is presented. Measures taken to repair and reuse damaged building elements are also given. Precautionary measures to avoid such failures in the future are discussed. © ASCE.

Abstract: This issue of the journal contains 25 papers presented at the Twelfth International Symposium on Desalination and Water Reuse, held in Malta in April 1991. The papers presented deal with evaporative processes and operations, electrodialysis, and material selection and corrosion. Topics discussed include control strategies for optimizing thermal desalination plants, the design of very large multistage flash evaporator units, cogeneration plants for combined electric power and drinking water production, brackish groundwater desalination using electrodialysis reversal, water desalination by ion-exchange hollow fibers, seeding with gypsum particles to prevent fouling during electrodialysis, desalination of electroplating effluents by electrodialysis, the use of inorganic membranes in electrodialysis, nitrate removal by electrodialysis, material selection for reverse osmosis desalination plants, a desalination plant corrosion experience database, the use of reduced chromium content stainless steels in desalination plants, materials selection for seawater reverse osmosis plants, the use of an austenitic nitrogen-alloyed stainless steel for seawater desalination, and localized corrosion behavior in welded stainless and structural steels in desalination plants. Authors: MacConochie I.O., Davis R.B., LeMessurier R.W.
Title: Alternative designs of integral tanks for advanced space transportation systems
Affiliations: NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA, United States; Kentron International, Inc., Hampton, VA, United States; Space Systems Division, United States; Systems Engineering Division, United States; Aerospace Structures Design Section, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacConochie, I.O., NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA, United States, Space Systems Division, United States; Davis, R.B., NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA, United States, Systems Engineering Division, United States; LeMessurier, R.W., Kentron International, Inc., Hampton, VA, United States, Aerospace Structures Design Section, United States
Abstract: Fully reusable launch vehicle concepts being studied for post-Shuttle era transports present major challenges for the structural design of large propellant tanks. The dominant structural elements are internal tanks for both cryogenic and noncryogenic propellants. These tanks must operate in a broad range of loading and thermal environments while meeting requirements for low weight and reusability. Several approaches to integral tank design are discussed and an analysis of a hot structure honeycomb sandwich tank for a circular body vehicle is presented. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1985, All rights reserved.

Authors: Cox G.N., Kusch M., DeNevi K., Edgar R.S.
Title: Temporal regulation of cuticle synthesis during development of Caenorhabditis elegans
Affiliations: Division of Natural Sciences, Thimann Laboratories, University of California, Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cox, G.N., Division of Natural Sciences, Thimann Laboratories, University of California, Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, United States; Kusch, M., Division of Natural Sciences, Thimann Laboratories, University of California, Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, United States; DeNevi, K., Division of Natural Sciences, Thimann Laboratories, University of California, Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, United States; Edgar, R.S., Division of Natural Sciences, Thimann Laboratories, University of California, Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, United States
Abstract: The pattern of cuticle protein synthesis during development of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has been studied using NaH14CO3. Both pulse-labeling and pulse-chase-labeling experiments indicate that synthesis of cuticle components occurs at high levels during the molting periods and at much reduced rates during the intermolt periods. No such discontinuous pattern is observed for the synthesis of total noncuticle macromolecules during development. The soluble and insoluble proteins of the cuticle, which comprise the inner and outer cuticle layers, respectively, follow similar patterns of synthesis during the two molts examined. At each molt the structural components of the cuticle account for approximately 10% of the total macromolecules labeled by NaH14CO3. No evidence is found for reuse of cuticle material between successive developmental stages of C. elegans. © 1981.

Authors: Jensen J.E., Witzell W.E.
Title: A fracture control program for the reusable space shuttle booster
Affiliations: General Dynamics/Convair Aerospace, P.O. Box 1128, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jensen, J.E., General Dynamics/Convair Aerospace, P.O. Box 1128, San Diego, CA 92112, United States; Witzell, W.E., General Dynamics/Convair Aerospace, P.O. Box 1128, San Diego, CA 92112, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the preliminary results of structural design and analysis efforts, and the development of preliminary fracture control plans for the principal structural components of a large reusable space shuttle booster. Included are a description of the space shuttle system, its characteristics and requirements, selected approaches for fracture control, and proposed fracture control plans. The requirements of the NASA planned space shuttle vehicle for full reusability has increased the need for high reliability, precision, and development in the fracture control approach. For the space shuttle booster, it is essential that fracture control be applied to all critical structural components (i.e., tanks, aero, surfaces, thrust structure, etc.) and the fracture control approach to each component be based on its individual design conditions, design characteristics, and sensitivities to fatigue and flaw growth. Since the fracture control approach of pressure vessels is of most interest, the plan will concentrate on the main propellant tanks although other parts of the vehicle will be mentioned. The selected fracture control plan integrates the fracture control activities over the design, manufacturing, qualification, and operation phases of the space shuttle program. The various elements of the fracture control plan include design criteria, fracture mechanics analysis, proof testing, trade studies of safe-life and fail-safe design approaches and materials, provisions for maintenance and inspection, non-destructive evaluation, and a record of vehicle usage and discrepancies during its service life. © 1972.
Index Keywords: PRESSURE VESSELS - Failure; ROCKET ENGINES - Boosters; SPACE SHUTTLES
